ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: A great class on general forest processes. Also very valuable from a general ecosystem dynamics point of view for building a framework to understand structure, function, process and the many factors shaping vegetation across landscapes.
I really enjoyed class. Sometimes I felt the class was too big. The material was incredibly useful and helpful.

Field trips: The GMF trip left a little to be desired, but that might have just been the weather. The ADK trip was amazing! I would strongly recommend that to anyone in this class in the future. In class:, Ann is a great teacher. She explains thing well, and in terms that students can understand. I wish that there were more lectures, rather than the student presentations at the end of the course. It also would have been nice to incorporate the readings into the lecture, rather that doing a big discussion at various points in the semester.

Ann is an outstanding teacher who explained concepts exceedingly well while providing personal antidotes and engaged the class in every lecture and class trip. She will be sorely missed at this University!
Ann is a firecracker of a personality in a great way, but is clearly ready to retire. Her stories are priceless.

I find Ann to be a very well organized and clear presenter. Her classes are structured in a way that is very easy to follow and I feel like I am getting invaluable knowledge from her experience on the ground and in the classroom.
Dr. Camp is a great professor who cares very much about her students learning the content of the course in a way that is valuable for them. Great course.

Question 1: The readings for the course were great, but it was not clear which readings were required and which we were responsible for knowing and would be assessed on in tests. The Oliver-Larson book was constantly referenced but no assigned readings were taken from the text. Question 4: The pace was ok, because lectures tended to get at the material from different angles, BUT the pace of individual courses was far too quickly paced. Less material per lecture with a few more lectures would be much more useful, in my opinion
Questions 5-7: I was unable to attend the one optional class field trip.
EXCELLENT COURSE.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Ann is a great lecturer and presents theory that is broadly applicable with examples for how it fits into specific situations. Very engaging and fun.
Annotated bibliography and presentation. I really enjoyed applying what I learned to my interests and hearing the same from others
I really enjoyed the lectures and field trips. Ann is an engaging teacher, and the slideshows and her descriptions illustrated the concepts very well.

Stand dynamics is very important for forest managers. I cam away from this course with an excellent understanding of the concepts. Students are encouraged to be engaged on many levels . Presentations,research and exams. Concepts are explained using New England forests as the backdrop but tropical elements and western elements were also included.
Most lectures were great, peer-led discussions were particularly valuable.
just well structured course overall. everything flowed nicely, and really enjoyed the student presentations more than any other student presentation i've ever been a part of, learned a ton from them.
I appreciated that ann supplemented lectures with student presentations and discussions the made the class much more interactive and made lectures more applicable.
I found the combination of student presentations and lectures to be timed perfectly.
This class is a great overview of forest development.

The subject matter of this course, is incredible and should be required for anyone interested in anything to do with forests or for that matter anything to do with environmental management. Cannot express how valuable I thought the material was.
Learning the basics of growth and yield modeling. Learning the overall stages of stand dynamics.
All aspects of this course is excellent.

The presentation slides had great visuals. The teacher moved at a nice, fast pace. The assignments were few but thoughtful and were effective learning tools. The field trips were great teaching tools. This course is a must for all FES students.
All aspects were wonderful. The course is well-thought-out, well-delivered, of-a-piece.

The teacher, classmates presentations, readings discussions. I learned a lot from the readings, studying the content and taking the exams. Also enjoyed my class group and relationship between us and Ann.
The wide range of material covered.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: N/A
Maybe an assignment in the first half of the course to keep students engaged

I sometimes wish that the course was a bit more complex. It seems like we skipped over a lot of quantitative data like stocking charts and models. I realize that you could take a whole course on each of those topics, but I think that would improve the course.
Class trip needed a little better organization otherwise nothing.

I felt that the final exam format was a little strange and inconsistent with the kind of thinking and evaluation present in the rest of the class. Our midterm was essays and short answers, which allowed students to really dig into a problem...the final exam was T/F, multiple choice, and fill in the blank, providing little opportunity to demonstrate knowledge application or work through the complex problems and issues that are a trademark of this class.

the tests are ridiculous. For somebody who is so conceptual in nature and wants us to be able to apply concepts in different situations, her tests are so particular. She has a specific answer in mind to her very vague question, which isn't always very obvious or the only possible answer. She'd then say well i'd probably mark it wrong but you could argue for your points back. And the number of questions that require knowing a specific definition, even if you understand the concept, were cray. Just a total mismatch from lecture style to exam style.
Midterms covers so much material, would be helpful if it was earlier so semester was more evenly broken up.

I though mainly in the pacing of the lectures and organization. Often unclear what exactly was required for readings etc. as often focus was placed on the unrequired readings. Also thought that the discussion groups could have been better, but this was likely due to class size.
Course lectures and slides seemed somewhat disorganized. The topics and content presented sometimes seemed disjointed and did not flow as well as possible.
I can't think of any.

The methods of testing used in the course were not congruent with the manner of instruction. For example, certain terms and scenarios may be used when describing tree growth in class. However, on mid-term/final examinations, the wording or scenarios presented may be new material not presented in this year's class, or the wording may be completely different. I believe the instructor was trying to challenge the students through the questions presented, however, the questions were often misleading and confusing which resulted in competent and well-prepared students not being fairly assessed for this course. I am not particularly concerned about my grade in this course, but if I were an undergraduate student concerned about grades, I would intentionally avoid this course because of the erratic and inconsistent grading. Also, a good teaching assistant is absolutely necessary (which we had this year in Elliott van de Kolk) as a liaison between the teacher and students to clarify questions. All told, however, this class was very informative, moved at a good pace, and was taught by a passionate teacher.
Probably the content was too much for the amount of time during the semester. Covering management practices after every chapter would have been very useful.

Many of the reading were very outdated. I understand the need to read old research papers to understand successional theory, but too many of the other research papers were outdated. I feel like I didn't learn enough about up to date theories and issues facing stand development.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes, although I'm not sure that the readings enhanced my learning that much. The discussion, especially about values, were very interesting.
Yes. It was excellent.
Great! Really added to the class.

Lectures were great (but see comments on pacing of lectures). The discussions I didn't find very valuable. Maybe could divide the class up into separate sections so that it was a bit more intimate and people would be more comfortable participating. Also I would eliminate the portion where students lead discussion, just leads to the leaders actually doing the reading and everyone else just answering their questions.
Yes. Student-led discussion sections on course readings were very helpful in better understanding material.
It was very effective, no improvement needed.
We only had field trips (no labs), and they correlated very well with lectures.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Yes
Great foundation course for the MF. I knew nothing about forest stands prior to this course
Extremely important for foresters and environmental managers.
absolutely great intro to understanding forest ecology.
Very relevant to my own research and interests.

This program will provide me with essential tools for talking to non-science persons who I will encounter frequently about management plans and decisions. I think that the most valuable thing that I have gained from this course is a new perspective on much of the environmental advocacy work that I hear and participate in. I am also very grateful for the beautiful images and metaphors that I have because of this course for the way that God works in the world.
Very well. Great first step to other courses I hope to take.

Regardless of what you study at FES, I feel that the concepts contained in this course are essential to an FES education. In particular the focus on the mis-conception of equilibrium in natural systems and the dynamic nature of forests. If I take nothing else away it will be this.

This semester, I had all my other courses planned around this one. I have done works related to forest conservation but never had a formal course in forestry. This course gave me a lot of perspectives in terms of forest management. I have learnt so much about trees in this class.
This is a foundation course that will lead into all aspects of forest-related studies at FES. It is necessary course that picks up where MODs leaves off. I am grateful to have taken it.
This course is an excellent fit. I plan to manage forest stands as part of my career, and this course provides essential information toward that end.

I have a background in Agriculture and work in organic agriculture and forestry in South America, They course was the best course I took this semester, it helped me a lot to understand the dynamcs of the forest giving me the foundations for forest management.
This course is necessary for my program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to refresh my forestry knowledge
To understand forests and ecosystem practices. This was the most general forest class.
To learn about forest stands and prep for silviculture
It was very related to the work and research that I want to do.
Need to understand the concepts behind stand dynamics.
Key to my program of study and a good basis for Silviculture in the spring.
so i could learn forest stand dynamics.
Helpful for my research

I took this course because I enjoyed Fire Ecology so much, because it seemed like a good way to get a broad overview of a "typical FES" course, and because every person I spoke to about what class not to miss mentioned Stand Dynamics and Silviculture.
To learn about forest ecology and how forests growth and develop over time
Interested in the material.

I have been considering a switch from the MEM to MF degree track, and Stand Dynamics seemed like an interesting introductory course to expose myself to the material that I would engage with throughout the MF track.
I loved trees and forest, this course just gave me the knowledge I needed for engaging in more forestry related works in the future.
It meets my degree requirements, and I heard many good things about the course from previous students.
Integral to my interests and career plans.
Because Im interested in tropical forest conservation, rehabilitation and restoration.
This course was a requirement and came highly recommended.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Very much
Yes
Yes, I am looking forward to taking silviculture in the spring
Yes.
Absolutely!
beyond.
yes
Yes!
Yes, absolutely.
By far. Course went much farther that I thought it would.
Absolutely!!!
I sometimes felt that content was repeated throughout the course and time could have been better spent expanding on concepts or introducing more advanced topics.
Yes. I did.
It exceeded my expectations.
Yes, completely.
Yes!

I had a basic understanding of forest stand dynamics from classes I took in undergrad. While taking this course I found that some the theories I had already learned were slightly different or conflicted with each other. I came to learn that that's just what they are, theories. It's up the scientist to take these concepts and apply them to a specific region/area. Forests are indeed very dynamic!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great to study with my peers. I think there was no negativity in working together.

we worked on a discussion session, and it went very well. I think one of the advantages working in a group is to know how other students are doing with this course at very deeper level and putting ideas together is always a very valuable experience to have in the real world.
I worked in some work groups during the field trips, and it was a good team building exercise where I got to know my classmates better.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: don't lag behind on the readings!
Talk to second years
Communicate with students who have taken this course before to understand concepts and expectations.
Ann is a great teacher! Pay attention in lecture and you will get a lot out of this class.
It is too bad that you will not get to take this class with Ann Camp.
Do the readings and make sure that you participate in discussions.
ann's retiring after next fall, so take it! Don't get hung up on her crazy exams, but do remember author names. She's got lots of great experience, stories, and makes the class enjoyable.
Keep up with readings

I would encourage them to collaborate and to begin preparing for the exams at the beginning of the semester. The exams were very challenging for me, and I think that the shared knowledge of students throughout the semester would have helped foster a sense of community and broadened the group's learning.
Take it! It's great!
It is an excellent course even if you think it might be outside of your field of interest!!!
Definitely take this course if interested in basic concepts required to better manage forests.
If you love trees and interested in forestry, this is tailored for you.
Care about it. Take what you're learning and observe forests around you. You will learn new things. Take this course.

If you plan to work with forests and have little to no background, take the course. If you have some background in forestry, talk with Prof. Camp about the appropriateness of the course. I loved the course!
Try to cover all the readings, and don't miss classes Ann is a wonderful teacher.
I highly recommend this course to all MF and MFS students, or to anyone interested in learning more about forest dynamics.
